div.stage: Enter Gillippus with Leucanthe in his arms.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: SO, here I'll rest my Burden; she begins to recover her strength, and Reason works apace; she call'd for help, but He carries her to the fire .nam'd no body, but at large, Gentle Souldier help.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: O save me, save me, Gentle Youth, I am betray'd.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Hark! again.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: Ha! Where am I? What place is this?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Now Gillippus, hide thy Snares cunningly, and then thou maist catch this Bird.

div.stage: [Gil. counterfeits himself dead, and lies by her.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: Ha! wet?— Good Heaven! now my fears return with my Reason, and I remember the danger I was in by a storm at Sea.— Ha! What's this? A man laid by my side? Sleeps he, or is he dead? Good Heaven protect me, How came I here?— Who's this? Gillippus? Bless me! he's so wicked, Me-thinks his Ashes should be dangerous. Hark! he groans. O! that faithful stranger, little does his soul fear what miseries his bounty has brought me. Hipparchus the Traitor call'd him, or my busie minde deceiv'd me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yonder's the fire which my Friend, will steer his desp'rate Course to. Ha! What do I see? Leucanthe, and Gillippus dead by her? Enter Hip.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Who's that nam'd Gillippus, Zenon?

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: What, alive?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Hipparchus! Nay, then I see my fate pursu es me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Art alive?— Ye Gods, take this in sacrifice while I offer that—

div.stage: [Kneels and kisses her hand, then points to Gil.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: 'Tis he, 'tis the Youth that sav'd me— O Sir, protect me from this Ravisher.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: If he scape me now I'm strangely curs'd; Do you stare, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I bleed apace.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I'm wounded.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Nay, it has a mouth, would it had this tongue in't.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You can fall when you are not dead; if thou jest now take that in earnest.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Hold, I'm unfit for such a sudden Exit; O she's lost, she's lost, for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: O Sir! Spare him a little time to throw off that load that sinks him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O Madam! to what danger has my mistake of service brought you? Are you not at war with all our Sex for the Treacheries of this Villain?

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: How do you, Sir? Alas, he faints!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I bleed apace, and I fear my wounds are deeper than I apprehended; for I feel a darkness now begin to close mine eyes. O Madam! Madam!

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: O! I fear he's lost; Good Gods, send some aid and counsel to a wretched Maid whom ye have pursu'd with change of cruel fates. O that I had dy'd ere I had seen this Youth; unfortunate Leucanthe, to see thy Love thus in the Cradle bloudy, born onely to add another cause of grief.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: This way I heard some body cry for help, and 'twas mingled with the noise of Swords; What's here, a man wet and wounded? Good Heaven! last night thou little expected'st such a land fate: More misery! Whence are they? A woman too? 'Tis some Murder sure. I'll take my Sword, those that could so destroy their youth will not spare my age.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: What art thou, Father, that pitiest our sad fates? Come hither and I'll teach thee how to mourn.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Is he dead thou mourn'st thus? Let me see his wounds, Hold up's head, he breaths, Bow him forward while I fetch a Balsam, whose sovereign power (if the vital parts be not perish'd) will restore his health.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: Run, run; O my Joy! if thou dy'st, upon thy Tomb I'll lay Marble rough as thy fortune, and on it set fix'd a living statue till with my tears I have pollish'd it.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: So, pour this Balsam into his wounds, and binde them up, and stay his head while I go finde the Hermit's Son, he shall help to bear him to my Cabin.

div.stage: Enter King, Eucratia, Sortanes, Hermit and his Son, with the Bodies of Lysimella and Pausanes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Bring 'em to yonder fire; and while Eucratia applies her charity to the Youth I'll assist Pausanes.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Eucratia! Who nam'd Eucratia?

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: Why, do'st thou know Eucratia?

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Know her! Yes, Leucanthe.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: Father!

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: 'Tis she.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.p: O ye Gods! your hands are visible through all this change.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Who are those about the fire?

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: Leucanthe and Theagines. O Sir! w'are blest beyond our Euc. goes to the fire and knows them. hopes.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Eucratia here too! O remove my doubts, by what fate are we met thus strangely?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Twill ask a longer time, Sir, than her charity now can spare to tell. In this time the Hermit is busie about Lysimella.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Father, they are all acquainted, and yet in my conscience they never appointed this meeting.

sp.speaker: Hermit.
sp.p: What's here? A womans breast in a Doublet? Ladies, some of your hands will be more proper here, this habit belongs not to the Sex it cloaths.

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: A woman!

sp.speaker: Hermit.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Sortanes, have you never seen that face? The King knows her.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.p: Yes, on my life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis Lysimella.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Here, O here! Who call'd wretched Lysimella?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Madam, your charity has found my Sister, my Friend, all that I call dear; and see if a cross fate has not attempted to snatch her hence: O persist in your charity, and a little dispense with your joy, and try to save her.

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: If my bloud could save her, to every vein I would a passage give, and through those thousand streams pursue her safety.

sp.speaker: Hermit.
sp.p: More of that Strong-water, and give him leave to breathe.

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: Here, put on this loose Roll, and hide her Disguise.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Some charitable hand convey me to Hipparchus, that from my dying lips I may breathe him comfort. About my neck you'll They turn to Gillippus .finde two golden Medals which I took from him and Pausanes bosome, in which (I heard one Perseus tell, who that day fell in battle) was writ in Characters their Names and Countrey, which yet they know not.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Perseus! Who can tell tidings of the aged Perseus?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: That can I—At the sack of Tunis he fell by my hands, when I took those youths Prisoners, they call'd him Father— O! I feel I'm sinking, but whither, O whither, Mercy, Mercy, Heaven.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: I am wrapp'd in amazement at these things; these are He takes the Medals from Gil. bosome. the Medals we hung about our Childrens necks; Which of these two was call'd Pausanes?

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: This.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: On thee then fall a blessing; but on thee my Son a thousand, thousand blessings; all that a weeping Father can with penitent He turns to Hip. tears call down fill thy days.

sp.speaker: Hermit,
sp.p: What have I liv'd to see?

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Oh, Leucanthe and Eucratia, see your long lost Brothers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Though my part be strange; yet these wonders make it seem nothing, there's such providence i'th chances; how fares my Lysimella?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Oh Brother, can you forgive this fault? I heard some body name Pausanes, where is he?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: There! and not come to Lysimella? oh! my fears will end this wrack, speak; by all the honours of thy youth, I conjure thee, is he dead, or no?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No, upon my life, he lives and is found a Prince.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: A Prince! and will not my Brother then—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why dost thou hide thy blushes in my bosom, think'st thou I can be cruel to Lysimella? no, no; since I saw thee I have felt thy pain, and now can love too, but dare not promise I shall be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: Can I add to your joys? if I can, Sir, let this Priest witness my vows to the King.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Will it please the King to retire to my homely Cell, 'tis free from storms, unless you bring 'em with you; I have liv'd long there, but never felt any save what my sins brought. Some skill too I have in herbs, and fortunate (I thank the gods) I have been in my attempts in Surgery; and hope they'll smile upon these Patients too, I find no danger of death amongst 'em: and when I have my Salvatory laid by, then I'll take up my Beads; for the Priest, I see, must compleat the joys of these happy pairs, my interest in which I'll no longer hide.— Oh speak Eucratia, think'st thou the gods will accept an offering from aged Memnon's hand again, that Puts off his disguise .once abus'd their altars by giving false Oracles, which thus they have reveng'd? if thou think'st they will, here I throw off my disguise, and from a Father and Priest, Sir, receive her.

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: My Father!

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Memnon, my Brother! oh welcome!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Let me interrupt your joys, lest their excess prove dangerous; and to the gods that have wrought this blessing, let us pass on to sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Lead on, Theagines, while we these young men bear off, on each of which a Virgin shall like their good genius wait; the story, how we came to be thus happy, we'll defer to a fitter time, when health and Hymen shall wait on these Princes, to set their Prisoners free, and prove Loves Fetters Liberty.
